text: ਬਿਨੁ ਸਬਦੈ ਸਭਿ ਦੂਜੈ ਲਾਗੇ ਦੇਖਹੁ ਰਿਦੈ ਬੀਚਾਰਿ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Without the Shabad, all are attached to duality. Contemplate this in your heart, and see.

transliteration.text: bin sabadai sabh dūjai lāgē dēkhah ridai bīchār .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਨਾਨਕ ਵਡੇ ਸੇ ਵਡਭਾਗੀ ਜਿਨੀ ਸਚੁ ਰਖਿਆ ਉਰ ਧਾਰਿ ॥੩੪॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, blessed and very fortunate are those who keep the True Lord enshrined in their hearts. ||34||

transliteration.text: nānak vadē sē vadabhāgī jinī sach rakhiā ur dhār .34.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. text: ਬਿਨੁ ਗੁਰ ਘਾਲ ਨ ਪਵਈ ਥਾਇ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Without the Guru, one's work is useless.

transliteration.text: bin gur ghāl n pavaī thāi .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Without the Guru, the mind is totally unsteady.

text: ਬਿਨੁ ਗੁਰ ਤ੍ਰਿਪਤਿ ਨਹੀ ਬਿਖੁ ਖਾਇ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Without the Guru, one is unsatisfied, and eats poison.

transliteration.text: bin gur tripat nahī bikh khāi .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. text: ਬਿਨੁ ਗੁਰ ਬਿਸੀਅਰੁ ਡਸੈ ਮਰਿ ਵਾਟ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Without the Guru, one is stung by the poisonous snake of Maya, and dies.

transliteration.text: bin gur bisīar dasai mar vāt .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak without the Guru, all is lost. ||38||

text: ਜਿਸੁ ਗੁਰੁ ਮਿਲੈ ਤਿਸੁ ਪਾਰਿ ਉਤਾਰੈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: One who meets the Guru is carried across.

transliteration.text: jis gur milai tis pār utārai .

translation.text: His sins are erased, and he is emancipated through virtue.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਮੁਕਤਿ ਮਹਾ ਸੁਖ ਗੁਰ ਸਬਦੁ ਬੀਚਾਰਿ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: How can the Shabad carry us across the terrifying world-ocean?"||43||

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.
